name: Seasonal Events
searchable: Seasonal Events Seasonal Events Attachment: 20170928203819-Hdr-Seasonal-Events.jpeg 20170928203819-hdr-seasonal-events.jpeg Sub-Sections-Nav Deck Events for every season With so much sunshine, beautiful surroundings, history and culture, there's always something to celebrate around the Bradenton Area. But be warned: you’ll probably get hungry reading about the Annual Seafood Festival, start tapping your foot and humming your favorite tune when you hear about the annual Blues Festival, or chant your favorite fight song when you discover all the world-class sporting events happening year-round. Although, we haven't heard any complaints yet. Html Container Attachment: 20171016111017-Spring-1.jpeg Spring Springtime is perhaps one of the best seasons to enjoy all the Bradenton Area has to offer. From fun outdoor events like food and music festivals, to sporting events like baseball spring training, springtime activities are all about getting outside to enjoy the lovely weather. Take advantage of all the Bradenton Area outdoors has to offer with a variety of fun, family-friendly events and activities. The Hernando De Soto Seafood Festival is widely recognized as one of Florida’s most outstanding events and features a great lineup of entertainment including the best local musicians, as well as nationally-known recording artists. Pittsburgh Pirates Spring Training can be found at LECOM Park, and is the perfect place to spend an afternoon watching America’s pastime played by some of the best athletes in the world. The Bradenton Farmers’ Market is a place where the community meets every Saturday – October through May – to enjoy fresh produce, local art, upbeat music, demonstrations by local chefs, and family activities. Blues, Brews and BBQ is an annual event serving up an extra special blend of great outdoor music, cold beer and tasty food at a family-friendly event that also spotlights the shops and restaurants that make Bridge Street “Anna Maria’s Hot Spot.” The Beach’N Food Truck & Music Festival is a free, family-friendly festival is a celebration of live music from local artists, tasty treats from some of the area’s favorite food trucks, brilliant works of art from local artists and unique crafts. 20171016111017-spring-1.jpeg Attachment: 20171016111017-Summer-2.jpeg Summer Here, summertime means finding the best ways to enjoy gorgeous sunny days and clear, serene nights. Celebrate summer with fireworks, minor league baseball, adrenaline-pumping outdoor adventures, and endless water activities. Make the most of summer with some of the best events and activities the Bradenton Area has to offer. 4th of July Fireworks displays can be enjoyed at a number of different places and celebrations in the Bradenton Area this summer, both on the mainland and out on the islands. Some of the best locations to watch include the Manatee River, LECOM Park, and pretty much any beach on Anna Maria Island. Adrenaline Row is a one-mile stretch of land with water on both sides offering insanely unique opportunities to thrill-seekers ready for an action-packed, heart-pounding day of fun on the water. The Bradenton Marauders is Bradenton’s very own minor league baseball team, and can be seen in action LECOM Park. The Tampa Bay Rays are Tampa Bay’s local pro-baseball team, playing just 30 minutes north of the Bradenton Area in St. Petersburg, making it an easy day trip to enjoy America’s pastime. 20171016111017-summer-2.jpeg Attachment: 20171016111017-Fall-1.jpeg Fall As temperatures begin to cool down in the Bradenton Area, the outdoor events and activities heat up. This fall, celebrate the arts, tour a citrus grove, pick pumpkins, sample the local fare at a food fest, enjoy an enchanting symphony on the sand and so much more. Attend a variety of events designed to get you out and about to enjoy fall in the Bradenton Area. Bayfest Pine Avenue is the longest-running festival on Anna Maria Island, and it's one of the most popular with music, food, arts and crafts. The Gulf Coast Rhythm & RibFest is a major annual fundraising event benefiting low income, and at-risk youth, and features live music, family-friendly games, and of course some of the best ribs in the world. The Hunsader Pumpkin Festival features live music, entertaining shows, exciting displays of daring stunts and a huge selection of pumpkins of all shapes and sizes. Symphony on the Sand offers an elegant evening on picturesque Coquina Beach with three hours of fine food and music provided by the 45-piece Anna Maria Island Concert Chorus & Orchestra. ArtsHop features live music, great food and the chance to experience some of the very best artwork the area has to offer. The Bradenton Blues Festival features an outstanding lineup of talented blues musicians as well as local craft beer, delicious specialty food vendors and more. The Bradenton Farmers’ Market is a place where the community meets every Saturday – October through May – to enjoy fresh produce, local art, upbeat music, demonstrations by local chefs, and family activities. The Mixon Fruit Farms Harvest Festival takes places throughout November and features great food, a health and business fair and a fun crafts fair. The Festival of the Skeletons Artwalk, inspired by the Day of the Dead, features shrines and altars throughout the Village dedicated to deceased artists, Mexican food, a memorial fence, skeleton crafts, strolling skeletons and more. The Tampa Bay Lightning are the local NHL ice hockey team, located just a breezy 45 minutes away at Amalie Arena in Tampa. The team plays 41 home games a year, making it easy to catch an ‘electrifying’ game while you’re in the area! The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are the local NFL football team, located about an hour away at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa. Take a day trip to one of their home games and enjoy a drink on their pirate ship! 20171016111017-fall-1.jpeg Attachment: 20171016111018-Winter-2.jpeg Winter What our winters lack in snowball fights and sledding they more than make up for with sunny days and fun-filled activities. This winter, enjoy live music, food fests, artistic events, farmer’s markets, a county fair, a race on the river and more. While everyone else is shoveling snow, those in the Bradenton Area will enjoy fun outdoor activities and events all season. The Manatee County Fair is a wholesome community tradition packed with a variety of things to see, do and eat. The Bradenton Area River Regatta has it all—speed, stars, showmanship—in a free spectacle that will have you holding your breath through every heart-pounding moment. The Cortez Fishing Festival celebrates the livelihood of Cortez Village, the commercial fishing industry, with great food, fun games and live music. ArtSlam invites you to engage in the creative process, experience temporary public art, and watch as teams of students and creatives take art out of the classrooms and studios and onto the streets. The Bradenton Farmers’ Market is a place where the community meets every Saturday – October through May – to enjoy fresh produce, local art, upbeat music, demonstrations by local chefs, and family activities. Christmas on Bridge Street is an annual, free, family-friendly holiday event with live music, theatrical performances, arts and crafts, handcrafted works of art, baked goods and even Santa himself. The North Pole Express All aboard! The North Pole Express departs every year from the Florida Railroad Museum in Parrish. This jolly ride transports you to a holiday wonderland in the North Pole. Families can enjoy the lights and decorations, unlimited hot chocolate and cookies, a model train display, and arts and crafts, and more. And no visit to the North Pole would be complete without a visit to Santa himself! 20171016111018-winter-2.jpeg

searchable: Venues Venues Attachment: 20171030144446-Hdr-Sports-General.jpeg 20171030144446-hdr-sports-general.jpeg Deck Want a warm-weather destination to host your next sporting event where everyone can relax and unwind after the game? The Bradenton Area supports a variety of sports--including top-notch sporting venues and a backdrop of beautiful islands ringed with sugar-white sand beaches. Article-Subsection Andersen RacePark Andersen RacePark is a go-kart and small-formula car facility that offers “arrive and drive” and professional driver development services. The racetrack sits on 18 landscaped acres and features a test track and opportunities for Indy car, stock car and drag racing. Learn more Article-Subsection Bradenton Area Convention Center Located on the scenic Manatee River, this flexible full-service facility has the space and staff necessary to make your event an overwhelming success. An ideal location for any indoor sporting event, the Bradenton Area Convention has a professional and friendly staff that is ready to assist you in planning and overseeing your function. With the ability to seat 4,000 people in a 34,000 square foot arena, there are also seven conference rooms available to help enhance your sporting event. Learn more Article-Subsection Bradenton Complexes The Bradenton Area offers a number of pristine, landscaped parks to host your next sporting event. With six top notch facility designed to accommodate large crowds and multiple events. These facilities include (but are not limited to) seven big league fields, 15 little league fields, five t-ball fields, 14 softball fields, 21 soccer fields, four football fields and eight outdoor courts. Learn more Article-Subsection Bradenton Motorsports Bradenton Motorsports is a great facility 1/8 Mile and ¼ mile drag racing and testing, grudge racing, car shows, and club track days. Standing tall with a start tower, 12,000 seat stadium and ample parking for all, this weekly racing is home to NMRA and NMCA. Learn more Article-Subsection Coquina and Manatee Beach Clear water and 15 miles of beautiful, white sand beaches combine to create some of the best backdrops during your sporting event. The beaches in the Bradenton, Anna Maria Island and Longboat Key area are a great place to host your next tournament and training. Learn more Article-Subsection Ellenton Ice and Sports Complex The 115,000-square-foot, “igloo-like” complex is a state-of-the-art facility on the Florida Gulf Coast offering recreational and entertainment activities for all ages. The complex features two NHL-regulation ice rinks, a 13,500-square-foot indoor soccer/ball hockey/lacrosse floor and a fitness center. Learn more Article-Subsection Fort Hamer Rowing Facility Located in the Bradenton Area, right off the Manatee River, the Fort Hamer Rowing Facility helps turn athletes into serious contenders. With an 8,500-square-foot fourbay boathouse and 15 miles (one-way) of rowable water surrounded by the natural, serene beauty of the Manatee County outdoors, there is no better place for teams of any size to train. Learn more Article-Subsection IMG Academy IMG Academy annually attracts nearly 200,000 athletes, coaches and spectators from 100 countries. In addition to its boarding preparatory school, IMG offers high-level training programs and hosts tournaments for amateur, collegiate and professional athletes and teams. Experience the benefit of state-of-the-art facilities and an entire staff dedicated to improving the skill level of athletes across a spectrum of different sports. Learn more Article-Subsection LECOM Park For more than 90 years, LECOM Park, formerly McKechnie Field, has been a source of fun and excitement in Bradenton. This 8,500+ person, state-of-the-art stadium is perfect for baseball training and tournaments. A 19,000-squarefoot boardwalk spanning the outfield provides an exceptional experience for both athletes and fans. Learn more Article-Subsection Pirate City Train where the pros train and take your team’s game to the next level. The Pittsburgh Pirates conduct their spring training in Bradenton at LECOM Park, and Pirate City is their state-of-the- art training facility near the stadium. You'll walk on 100% Bermuda grass among four fields in a cloverleaf design. Spectators can watch from a common area in the middle and entry to the fields can be secured for ticket sales purposes. Learn more Article-Subsection Premier Sports Campus The Premier Sports Campus, with 23 multi-purpose FIFA regulation fields (eight lighted), and more than 140 acres, can support a variety of field-related events. Underground field irrigation allows for efficient water drainage and improves timeout weather management. The campus is available to host local, state, regional and national level events. Learn more Article-Subsection State College of Florida (SCF) Home of the Manatees, the State College of Florida campus in Bradenton offers a number of facilities and accommodations. With the ability to host baseball, softball, basketball, tennis and volleyball you can play on the same grounds as college players. Learn more

searchable: How To Apply How To Apply Attachment: 20171030144446-Hdr-Sports-General.jpeg 20171030144446-hdr-sports-general.jpeg Deck Sponsorship Opportunities It is the intent of the Bradenton Area Sports Commission (BASC) Sponsorship Program to facilitate and foster the growth of sporting events in Manatee County and increase visitor travel, hotel stays, traffic to restaurants and other attractions in Manatee County which will generate both out-of-county and out-of-state economic impact. Article-Subsection Sports Event Sponsorship Program The BASC has created the Sports Event Sponsorship Program to assist event organizers with funding towards their event in Manatee County. Events will be awarded funding through an online software administered by the Sports Commission staff. There is an application and post event process. Please complete the application and submit to the BASC. If approved you will receive an approval email outlining all requirements. Each funded event will be required to submit a post report, with backup documentation, within 30 days of the event in order receive funding. Below are requirements and backup documentation for funding. All sporting organizations and events are eligible and will be evaluated based upon the following requirements and backup documentation: Event collateral showing Bradenton Area Sports Commission logo AND URL. (Flyers, banners, signs, e-blast, website, etc) Completed Hotel Information Form or Housing Bureau Documentations Copy of event photos or action photos during the course of play Proof of participant involvement (Schedules, rosters, etc) Proof of spectator involvement (Picture of crowd, ticket sales, etc) Copy of paid invoice Apply for a sponsorship.

searchable: History History Attachment: 20170929201452-Hdr-Crosley-Estate.jpeg History 20170929201452-hdr-crosley-estate.jpeg Deck While Powel Crosley Jr. never made more than $50 a week before he was 30, by age 33 he had amassed a fortune selling auto parts through the then-unheard-of medium of direct mail. Article-Subsection Powel Crosley, Jr. Industrialist. Inventor. Visionary. While Powel Crosley Jr. never made more than $50 a week before he was 30, by age 33 he had amassed a fortune selling auto parts through the then-unheard-of medium of direct mail. His son wanted a wireless radio, so he perfected and manufactured the first low-priced crystal set, the hugely successful "Harko," opening that entertainment medium to the masses. He ventured into radio broadcasting to sell more radios and at 500,000 watts had the most powerful station in the world. His radio station – The Nation's Station, WLW – was the proving ground for the early careers of many who went on to global stardom. His television station became the first NBC affiliate, and Crosley's own Cincinnati Reds baseball team became the first sports program ever broadcast in color. In his lifetime, Powel Crosley Jr. used his fortune and his enterprise to assist many others up the ladder of success. His many charitable contributions provided a teaching environment for tens of thousands of young men and women. By the end of his life, he had invented, developed, manufactured or produced: The first compact economy car (1939) First auto radio (1930) Electric wagon (1900) Shelvador refrigerator 500,000-watt radio station (1934) Night baseball (1935) Soap operas (1934) Facsimile machine (1940) First 4-wheel disc brakes (1939) 35mm camera Airplanes (4 different) First radio broadcast from an airplane (1930) Phonographs, scalp massagers, canoes, furniture, baby carriages, washing machines, stoves and bed-cooling systems. In 2013, Powel Crosley, Jr. was inducted into the Radio Hall of Fame.Watch the video The History of the Powel Crosley Estate Powel Crosley built the Florida winter home for his wife, Gwendolyn, in 1929. The two-and-a-half-story Mediterranean mansion was built in the southwest corner of Bradenton on a 60-acre parcel of land on Sarasota Bay adjacent to the John Ringling Estate. The 11,000-square-foot home has 21 rooms and 10 baths, and an adjacent carriage house has room for three cars and servants' quarters on the second floor. Originally the mansion had a swimming pool, a seaplane dock and yacht basin. The home featured many innovations for its time, including a steel frame encased in cast stone, embedded pipes and wiring, and a 135-day construction schedule. Placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1982, Seagate was saved from commercial development and purchased for renovation by Manatee County, which operates it as a meeting, conference and event venue. The intention of the Exhibition is to provide visitors with an unparalleled experience by immersing the viewer into the lives of two of the world greatest artists that ever lived.   The Exhibition is divided into Michelangelo's and DaVinci’s sculptures, paintings, architecture, inventions and machines.  Notable statues include the life size head of David, as well as the Pieta, whose depiction of Mary holding Jesus' body grips the viewer with maternal grief. Elsewhere, visitors get up close to examine the details in his famed Sistine Chapel frescos. High-quality reproductions let guests gaze at The Creation of Adam in the sort of detail known only to professional restorers.  DaVinci’s interactive inventions are highlighted and on display are his licensed reproductions masterpieces framed to the exact size of the original artwork.  The secret of DaVinci’s Mechanical Lion is revealed.       Divine Michelangelo & DaVinci: Side by Side Exhibition Hours:   Monday through Saturday: 10:00am till 5:00pm   Sunday: 12:00 noon till 5:00pm   Open New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day Admission Prices: Adults: $15.95 Seniors/Teachers: $13.95   Children: (4-12): $11.95   Children: 3 & under Free (with paying adult)       Groups (20 or more - Groups must be prearranged):   Student Groups: $7.00   Adult Groups: $11.00         Docent Guided Tour Times:   Monday through Thursday: 1:00pm   Friday and Saturday: 11:00am – 1:00pm – 3:00pm   Sunday: 1:00pm – 3:00pm       Private Events:   Cater your next Private or Corporate Event  for a “once in a lifetime” inspirational evening!   Call 941-209-1236 – Pricing available upon request       Divine Michelangelo & DaVinci: Side by Side   Through April 30, 2015   1005 1st Ave. West   Bradenton, FL 34205   Phone: 941-209-1236   www.discoverdavinci.com

But what turtles lack in speed they make up for in endurance. Sea turtles have been tracked swimming thousands of miles over a single migration season.Attachment: 20171004190344-Hdr-Athletes-Of-The-Sea.jpeg 20171004190344-hdr-athletes-of-the-sea.jpeg Deck Super Athletes of the Sea Sea turtles aren’t known for their speed. Even when swimming, turtles top out a hair over twenty miles an hour. But what turtles lack in speed they make up for in endurance. Sea turtles have been tracked swimming thousands of miles over a single migration season. Html Container Attachment: 20170914134236-Large-Turtle.png The Tour de Turtles, an annual marathon event created by the Sea Turtle Conservancy, tracks these aquatic Olympians as they begin their arduous journey from beaches in Costa Rica, Panama, Nevis, Anna Maria Island and other parts of Florida using satellite telemetry. But despite its name, the Tour de Turtles isn’t for fame, glory and shiny gold medals, though. Its purpose is to encourage and support research, education and protection of the natural habitats upon which sea turtles depend. For this, the 10th year of the Tour de Turtles, the Waterline Marina Resort & Beach Club and Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch & Shorebird Monitoring (AMITW) have partnered to raise awareness of the harmful effects light pollution has on sea turtles’ nesting behavior. The Waterline and AMITW are sponsoring Eliza Ann, a female loggerhead turtle who recently laid her eggs on Anna Maria Island. On June 20, a crowd of Bradenton Area locals, visitors, and staff and volunteers from The Waterline and AMITW were on hand as Eliza Ann made her way back into the sea. For three months, visitors to tourdeturtles.com can follow Eliza Ann and her competitors as they travel among the currents. The turtle that travels the farthest over the three-month period will be announced as the winner of this year’s marathon. Even though we’re rooting for Eliza Ann to win, we’re happy that people are excited to support such an important cause. Go, Eliza, go! 20170914134236-large-turtle.png

Html Container Attachment: 20170918225111-On-The-Beaches.png On the Beaches No vacation to the Bradenton Area is complete without a trip to the beach. Lucky for you, you have a lot of beaches to choose from. From the northern tip of Bean Point on Anna Maria Island to the secluded shores of Greer Island, you’ll find that every beach has its own flavor. Anna Maria Island is basically one long stretch of beautiful beaches, and they all offer something different. You can play beach volleyball and other sports at the Manatee Public Beach. At Palma Sola Bay, you can ride horses and try flyboarding. At Holmes Beach, you can enjoy fine dining with your feet in the sand. Further south, Longboat Key offers tranquil beach settings and abundantly serene getaways. Explore more of the Bradenton Area’s best beaches to find places to eat, stay and be merry. Take the Beach Finder Quizto find the precise beach that’s perfect for you. From shelling at Coquina Beach to shopping at Bradenton Beach, there’s something for everyone. 20170918225111-on-the-beaches.png Attachment: 20170918225924-Around-Town.png Around the Town After a trip to the beaches, make your way across Palma Sola Bay toward the city of Bradenton, where you’ll find Snooty hanging out at the South Florida Museum. He’s the oldest living manatee in captivity and acts as a mascot for the nature and wildlife preservation efforts in the Bradenton Area. Along with the museum, Bradenton is where you’ll find some of the area’s best restaurants. From upscale waterfront dining at Pier 22 to laid-back burger joints like the Shake Pit, you’re never far from your next good meal in Bradenton. And stick around for dessert at Sugar Cubed, located next to creative art galleries in the Village of the Arts, the largest live-work community in Florida. It’s a one-of-a-kind place where you can walk through homes and view paintings, sculptures and other artwork made by the homeowners. Bradenton is also where you’ll find McKechnie Field, one of the oldest ballparks in Florida. Catch the Pittsburgh Pirates for spring training or the Bradenton Marauders all season long. Nearby, the beer is flowing. Local breweries like Motorworks Brewing and Darwin Brewing Company are located in the heart of Bradenton and are making craft brews that are true to the flavor of the city. 20170918225924-around-town.png Attachment: 20170918225111-The-Groves.png In the Groves Travel east to a place as peaceful as the Bradenton Area’s most serene beaches. The area’s farmlands are vast, calm and home to some of the freshest fruits and veggies in Florida. Go to O’Brien Family Farms to pick fruit right from the vine. Dakin Dairy Farm lets you bottle-feed baby calves. And Mixon Fruit Farm is where you can tour the orange groves that Florida is famous for. But the farmlands aren’t just for fruits and veggies. Local wineries like Rosa Fiorelli Winery and Bunker Hill Winery let you get a taste of the Bradenton Area in a bottle. Do some wine tasting and head down to Lakewood Ranch for a round of golf at a course that turns the natural beauty of the area into your own personal playground. If golf isn’t your thing, Lakewood Ranch has restaurants and shops that are worth a trip away from the beach. Now that you know more about the lay of the land, it’s time to get to the Bradenton Area. Click here to learn more about the best ways to get here and get around. 20170918225111-the-groves.png

Enjoy a Florida-brewed craft beer Get a refreshing taste of the Bradenton Area with a locally brewed craft beer from one of the many breweries. Article-Subsection 3. Dock and dine After spending a long day out boating you’ll surely be searching for somewhere to chow down. Fortunately, dining on the water in the Bradenton Area is always easy. Just stick your boat in a slip at Riverhouse Reef & Grill, Starfish Co., Anna Maria Oyster Bar, or one of the many other dock & dine restaurants that are sure to “wet” your appetite. Attachment: 20171201205414-Bean-Point-On-Ami-Sfpkybd6Eofpbdvicfrblqp-Rgb-S.jpeg 4. Get a massage on the beach What’s better than a massage while you’re on vacation? Paint a sand dollar Everyone will want a piece of the Bradenton Area to take home for lasting memories. But for a truly unique souvenir that is all your own, try painting a sand dollar at Shiny Fish Emporium on Anna Maria Island. And don’t forget the glitter! Article-Subsection 6. Luckily, Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport is just a hop, skip, and a jump away from the Bradenton Area’s sugar white sand beaches. A 3-day long event, the Blues Fest is always a foot-tapping good time! 20171204162944-31726906886-c4a935730b-z.jpeg Article-Subsection 12. Take your pick The Bradenton Area is well known for its beaches, but head a little further east and you’ll find a lush farmland. For the freshest of fresh fruit, head to O’Brien Family Farms for a U-Pick extravaganza including strawberries, tomatoes, carrots, and more! Article-Subsection 13. Get folksy Take a class at the Florida Maritime Museum’s Folk School! These classes teach near-lost heritage skills that have been passed down through the generations. Highlights include soap making, ancestry, wine making, knot tying and storytelling. Article-Subsection 14. Paddle around The ecology of Florida is incredibly unique – in fact, the only areas that you’ll find a higher level of diversity of wildlife is in the tropical rainforest and coral reefs – and there’s no better way to explore it than with a kayak. Tour services like Beach Bums and Happy Paddler lead you through the Bradenton Area’s clear blue waters and into its intricate mangrove system. Attachment: 20171204163335-Andersen-Snkpfphtupc8T7Ilfof04Su18Q0Ablzbh.jpeg 15. Go top speed The Bradenton Area can be paradise for thrill seekers too! At Andersen Race Park, you can speed around in karts and leave your friends in the dust. 20171204163335-andersen-snkpfphtupc8t7ilfof04su18q0ablzbh.jpeg Article-Subsection 16. Stay comfortably The Bradenton Area has a wide variety of accommodations, but if you’re looking for an extra comfortable space considering splurging on a vacation home rental. From sprawling 6-bedroom modern homes to cozy beach cottages, you’ll find it hard to part from your home-away-from-home. Attachment: 20171204163655-Performing-Arts-Sl5Znxczvduhafx3Hgjouvn-Cmyk-S.jpeg 17. Take in a show You don’t have to hit Broadway to catch an awesome stage play. The Bradenton Area is home to the Manatee Performing Arts Center, a state-of-the-art theater with professional-grade plays that will make your emotions soar. 20171204163655-performing-arts-sl5znxczvduhafx3hgjouvn-cmyk-s.jpeg Article-Subsection 18. Book your return Once you’ve experienced the treasures of the Bradenton Area, you’ll understand why it has a 94% return rate. Occupancy fills up fast so be sure to start planning your return vacation as soon as you get home! Html Container

From private spots on the beach to dinner for two overlooking the sunset, there’s a perfect place for you to start forever. As for working up the courage to ask the question, that’s up to you. Html Container Article-Image-Grid Bean Point Is there a better place to get engaged than the beach? Actually, yes. Bean Point isn’t just a beach – it’s a secluded sanctuary of loveliness. Located at the northern-most tip of Anna Maria Island, the breathtaking beauty of the water goes on for miles. A riptide off the shore means it’s not the best place for swimming, which just makes it all the better for private moments. It’s quiet, picturesque and unforgettable during sunset – the perfect combination of things for asking the big question. Article-Subsection Beach Horses Looking for something even more unforgettable than a beach proposal? Just add horses. It’s called horse surfing and you can only do it with BeachHorses. Book your one-of-a-kind experience to ride horses right on the beach and even in the waters of Palma Sola Bay! Spend the day doing an activity that even the most romantic Hollywood movies would be jealous of. Just make sure to leave the ring in your bag before you go horse surfing – you wouldn’t want to lose it in the middle of the excitement. Article-Subsection Art Walk The beach isn’t the only place to make a memorable moment. Take an art walk in the unique Village of the Arts to get inspired by some of the most unique home galleries you’ll ever see. It’s the largest live-work community in Florida and a world of its own. Walk through romantic galleries, eat at intimate candle-lit restaurants and ask the big question in style. Attachment: 20170917125726-Dining-Couple.png Waterfront Dining If going out to dinner is more your taste, you’re in for a treat here. Choose from numerous waterfront dining options that each have their own flavor. Pier 22 overlooks the calm waters of the Manatee River. Sandbar Restaurant lets you eat at a table right on the beach. And Beach Bistro offers picturesque views the water while serving up a fine dining experience. They’re all a little different but all equally great places to enjoy the most unforgettable dinner of your life. 20170917125726-dining-couple.png Attachment: 20170917125727-Robinson-Preserves-Couple.png Robinson Preserve Sometimes all you need to pop the question is a place where you can be all alone. At Robinson Preserve, the only thing you’ll be surrounded by is the natural beauty of the Bradenton Area. Walk along the boardwalk and watch roseate spoonbills, white pelicans and even eagles fly overhead. Then, make your way up the 40 foot tall observation tower to take it all in. Once you ask the question, you’ll feel like you’re on top of the world. The Bradenton Area isn’t just a place for proposing. Here are some places to find the best fish tacos on your next vacation to the Bradenton Area. Html Container Article-Subsection Wicked Cantina Wicked Cantina’s name is no coincidence. It’s because their burgers, seafood and fish tacos are wicked good. Located on Bradenton Beach, it’s your one-stop beachside taco shop. Enjoy everything from fried shrimp tacos to classic carnitas street tacos drizzled with their famous super spicy Wicked Sauce. Article-Subsection Birdrock Taco Shack The Village of the Arts is where you find the most artistic creations in Bradenton. It’s also home of Birdrock Taco Shack, one of the most creative taco shops around. Tuna, lobster, blue crab and more are all on the menu. Order up and enjoy an art walk through the boutiques, galleries and shops. Article-Subsection The Waterfront Restaurant Looking for some fish tacos that are a little more refined? Look no further than The Waterfront Restaurant. Their premium black grouper tacos are topped with jicama slaw and packed with flavor. One bite and you’ll see why they’re such a local favorite. Article-Subsection Star Fish Company Seafood doesn’t come any more authentic than at Star Fish Company in Cortez Fishing Village. Residing in one of the oldest working fishing villages in the country, their fish is fresh caught from the sea and tastes so good that it needs no special ingredients or fancy plating – it’s just great, fresh seafood that’s sure to make your mouth water. Article-Subsection Tide Tables Another option in Cortez is Tide Tables. Their fresh grouper tacos are big on flavor and, well, big in size. They come with a side of some of the best sauce in the Bradenton Area and a heaping order of fries. And its location right on the water makes it all the better. Article-Subsection O’Bricks Tempura fried, blackened or grilled – there’s a fish taco for every taste bud at O’Bricks. Located in downtown Bradenton, it’s known for its laid-back atmosphere and great variety of food and drinks. But the fish tacos are a must-try for first time visitors. Article-Subsection Poppo’s Taqueria Not a seafood lover? Head over to Pine Avenue and customize your order at Poppo’s Taqueria. All of their choices are great, but if you’re feeling adventurous try the wild boar carnitas. And wash it down with one of the many local brews on tap. Finished with fish tacos? Article-Subsection By car The best way to get around town is with your car or a rental. It gives you the freedom to set your own schedule, go with the flow, and even carpool with friends or other members of your group. Public Transportation Public transportation networks are established, but they are limited by route and frequency. Anna Maria Island has its own free public trolley transport system, aside from the MCAT, providing transportation from the north to the south end of the island every 20-30 minutes. The MCAT provides transportation throughout the larger Bradenton Area including Longboat Key. To see routes and schedules, please click here. Other options Alternatively, go "green" and explore the natural beauty of the area by foot, bike, scooter, segway or electric golf cart. Although the range will be limited, they are great to explore the area more thoroughly. There are several rental locations around. To find the one that will be closest to you check out our "Play" section and see what other activity options you have during your stay.

name: Movie Makers Taking Notice of the Sunshine State
searchable: Movie Makers Taking Notice of the Sunshine State Movie Makers Taking Notice of the Sunshine State Attachment: 20170929201903-Hdr-Film.jpeg 20170929201903-hdr-film.jpeg Article-Subsection Movie Makers Taking Notice of the Sunshine State PARRISH, Fla. - Hollywood movie makers are taking notice of the Sunshine State. Fourteen major movies were filmed in Florida in 2012. Some of the most noticeable titles include "Iron Man 3" and "Spring Breakers."Local TV and film makers are also making a mark in Florida. Les McDowell is filming his cable/internet series called “Dry Creek” on his property. His land in Parrish looks like a country town from the late 1800’s. The town is equipped with staples like a saloon, general store and church.“It’s pretty much a replica of what old Florida would really be like way before Disney. It’s a lot like Little House on the Prairie, you take the Waltons and you take Mayberry and you mix them all up in a pot and that’s Dry Creek,” said McDowell.McDowell created the fictional town after being laid off from his job in 2009.“I got to the point where I wanted to reinvent myself,” said McDowell.Hundreds of local actors and crew members help make Dry Creek a reality.Check out the 1800's town here on The List Sho An independent film maker is also utilizing Dry Creek, but for something a little different. Christian Schwier and his crew at Litewave Media are making the Sci-Fi film “The Skyship Chronicles.” Part of the movie is being filmed in Parrish.“We’ve got a story about a young girl who has escaped from an evil villain inventor, and then we fast-forward to the future,” said Schwier.The movie should be available for the public in April.

name: Celebrating the Holidays in the Bradenton Area
meta_title: Celebrating the Holidays in the Bradenton Area
meta_description: From boat parades for Christmas to New Year's on the beach, here's just a few ways to celebrate the holidays in the Bradenton Area.
searchable: Celebrating the Holidays in the Bradenton Area Celebrating the Holidays in the Bradenton Area From boat parades for Christmas to New Year's on the beach, here's just a few ways to celebrate the holidays in the Bradenton Area.Attachment: 20171206183439-Small-Shell-Hunter-S6Hzgslu8Slvzzocvwpku5P-Rgb-L.jpeg 20171206183439-small-shell-hunter-s6hzgslu8slvzzocvwpku5p-rgb-l.jpeg Deck Christmas Html Container Article-Subsection Christmas on Bridge Street Celebrate Christmas in paradise with Christmas on Bridge Street on Anna Maria Island. This holiday spectacular includes holiday shopping, family bonding and – perhaps most exciting – a hot chocolate bar. Article-Subsection The lights at University Town Center This high-end shopping district is beautiful every day of the year, but during the holidays they go all out! Whether you’re strolling around the lake at Nathan Benderson Park or cruising down University Parkway, this glittering winter wonderland is sure to spark holiday cheer. Attachment: 20171206183942-Photo-2-Wiggins-General-Store.jpeg A Florida Cracker Christmas Transport yourself back in time with the Manatee Village Historical Park’s Florida Cracker Christmas! At this family-fun event the park dresses itself up inside and out to reflect Christmas styles and celebrations from the Victorian era and includes artisans, food vendors, “make-and-take” seasonal crafts for adults and youth, special exhibits, vintage silent films and more. And you won’t want to miss the ornately decorated 9-foot Christmas tree in the 1887 Old Meting House Church. 20171206183942-photo-2-wiggins-general-store.jpeg Article-Subsection Christmas Dinner The Bradenton Area is a food lover’s playground all times of year, but on Christmas day a select few restaurants put out a truly fabulous spread. For a tasty Christmas supper, load up the family and head to one of the excellent dining establishments such as Arts + Eats Restaurant in Village of the Arts, Polo Grill in Lakewood Ranch or Euphemia Haye on Longboat Key. Attachment: 20171206184105-Boat-Parade-679-Credit-R-Kennedy-For-Acva.jpeg The Manatee River Boat Parade Do a holiday parade Florida style. The Manatee River Holiday Boat Parade – a staple of the Bradenton Area’s holiday celebrations for years – is a can’t-miss Christmas light extravaganza. For the best viewing experience, kick back with a meal and a cocktail at the deck at Pier 22 in Bradenton or Riverhouse Reef & Grill in Palmetto. 20171206184105-boat-parade-679-credit-r-kennedy-for-acva.jpeg Deck New Year's Eve Html Container Attachment: 20171206184913-Crosley-Wedding-Sfofaexs1F6Nigc-Tnk7Ho-Rgb-L.jpeg The Powel Crosley Estate Start your new year off in this elegant Mediterranean-revival waterfront mansion at the Powel Crosley Estate’s Speakeasy Soiree. Here, your evening will include fine dining, card games, dancing under the stars and a midnight champagne toast. 20171206184913-crosley-wedding-sfofaexs1f6nigc-tnk7ho-rgb-l.jpeg Article-Subsection Main Street Live! Downtown Bradenton hosts a blast of a good time on New Year’s Eve. The party, which is hosted on a pedestrian-only closed of Main Street, includes food trucks, live music, games and dancing. And it all leads up to a countdown to the ball drop at midnight! Article-Subsection The Beaches of Anna Maria Island Of course, one of the most relaxing ways to ring in the new year is on the soft sand beaches of Anna Maria Island. Grab dinner at one of the many restaurants hosting a NYE meal like Beach House, Beach Bistro or Bridge Tender Inn, and then kick back and wait for the show to start. The fireworks shoot off at midnight and you’re sure to see them from any spot on the beach.

meta_title: Things to Do When the Beach Fatigue Sets In
meta_description: In the Bradenton Area the beach is always at the top of your mind for vacation fun. But after a few days, you may notice that beach fatigue has set in and looking for different ways to spend your vacation days. Here are some of the top things to do in the Bradenton Area for when you’re ready to get away from the beach.
searchable: Things to Do When the Beach Fatigue Sets In Things to Do When the Beach Fatigue Sets In In the Bradenton Area the beach is always at the top of your mind for vacation fun. Here are some of the top things to do in the Bradenton Area for when you’re ready to get away from the beach.Attachment: 20180815141517-Downtown-Scene-S4Nfwow69-G04Fhab3Nsgep-Rgb-S.jpeg 20180815141517-downtown-scene-s4nfwow69-g04fhab3nsgep-rgb-s.jpeg Deck In the Bradenton Area the beach is always at the top of your mind for vacation fun. But after a few days, you may notice that beach fatigue has set in and looking for different ways to spend your vacation days. Here are some of the top things to do in the Bradenton Area for when you’re ready to get away from the beach. Html Container Article-Subsection Village of the Arts The Bradenton Area is home to one of the largest live-work artist communities in the country. Village of the Arts is an eclectic neighborhood made up of brightly painted old Florida bungalows that house art studios, restaurants, galleries and more. This vibrant community is the best way to spend an afternoon dining on fantastic food and shopping for a unique souvenir. Attachment: 20180815142959-Eee.png Andersen RacePark Adrenaline junkies with love the fast-pace excitement at Andersen RacePark! Strap on your helmet and speed around their one-mile professional style go-kart track complete with 13 turns. You’ll have a blast racing around their track and leaving your friends and family in the dust. 20180815142959-eee.png Article-Subsection Downtown Bradenton In Downtown Bradenton you can stroll the shops of Old Main Street and enjoy the Riverwalk along the glimmering Manatee River. Grab an ice cream cone at Corwin’s and stroll down this 1.5 mile stretch packed with loads of fun including a splash pad, fishing dock, outdoor living rooms, a skate park, a playground and more. And be sure to check out the delicious downtown restaurants like Pier 22 on the river and O’Bricks on Old Main Street. Attachment: 20180815143019-Sss.png Farm Tours Out east you’ll find plenty of fun opportunities in the Bradenton Area farms. At Dakin Dairy Farm you can take a hayride through the stalls and see how milk is made starting with the cow and ending with the bottling. You also won’t want to miss out on their amazing chocolate milk! At Mixon Fruit Farms, you’ll take a tram tour through an authentic Florida orange grove and make a stop at their exciting wildlife rescue center. 20180815143019-sss.png Attachment: 20180815143043-Ttt.png The Gamble Plantation Historic State Park Take a step back in time and tour the last remaining antebellum plantation in South Florida. Built in 1850, the Gamble Mansion stands on 16 acres which also include the 1872 Victorian-style Patten House, a visitor center, and picnic tables. Be sure to do one of their tours with a park ranger to learn all about this very special monument! 20180815143043-ttt.png Article-Subsection The Florida Maritime Museum Just over the bridge from Anna Maria Island in Cortez Fishing Village, you’ll find the hidden gem that is The Florida Maritime Museum. Housed in the 1912 Cortez schoolhouse, this museum is dedicated to preserving Florida’s commercial fishing history and telling stories about the people who have called Cortez home for over a decade. While you’re there, be sure to check out their Folk School to learn some traditional Florida skills like soap making, ancestry, painting with a fish, net minding and so much more!

searchable: Exploring a Community Staple - The South Florida Museum Exploring a Community Staple - The South Florida Museum We thought we knew everything there was to know about the museum after making several visits over the years. That was until recently when we sat down with the museum’s Communications Director, Jessica Schubick, and their Provost, Jeff Rodgers. During our interview, we learned that there is so much more to this long-standing museum than meets the eye.Attachment: 20180425113015-Southfloridamuseum-Sgt79Xfij32Ux24Jun3Jjpn-Rgb-L.jpeg 20180425113015-southfloridamuseum-sgt79xfij32ux24jun3jjpn-rgb-l.jpeg Html Container Article-Subsection For any long-term resident of the Bradenton Area, the South Florida Museum has always been a standing fixture in their lives. We thought we knew everything there was to know about the museum after making several visits over the years. That was until recently when we sat down with the museum’s Communications Director, Jessica Schubick, and their Provost, Jeff Rodgers. During our interview, we learned that there is so much more to this long-standing museum than meets the eye. Attachment: 20180425114604-Img-Ss0192.png So much so, that when prompted with ‘how are we ever going to fit all of this into one story’, both Jessica and Jeff responded “you can’t.” With that in mind, where does one even begin to explain everything the South Florida Museum has to offer? “The South Florida Museum is a natural history and cultural history museum focused on Florida,” Jessica offered. That sounded simple enough, but then she continued, “The museum tells the story of earth, life, and beyond through Florida as a microcosm,” instantly expanding our understanding of the museum’s offerings ten-fold. The museum includes the main natural history exhibit, along with the Bishop Planetarium and the Parker Manatee Rehabilitation Aquarium, which is a second-stage stage center where injured or orphaned manatees are cared for before they are released back into the wild. But the South Florida Museum isn’t just a small place for artifacts - it’s a staple of the Bradenton Area community. Originally located on the Memorial Pier, the museum has been part of Bradenton’s history since 1946. 20180425114604-img-ss0192.png Attachment: 20180425114841-Img-0201.png “Our founding collection, which can still be found in the museum, was the collection of Florida-based amateur archaeologist Montague Tallant,” Jessica told us. Despite his career as a furniture store owner, Tallant ended up saving much of Florida’s history through his hobby. When the Smithsonian Institute expressed interest in his vast collection, local leaders came together to acquire nearly half of his artifacts in an effort to preserve their area’s history. 20180425114841-img-0201.png Attachment: 20180425115203-Bishopstars-Sk2Zch1Wzvekdvttz50Bcis18Q0Ablzbh-Rgb-L.jpeg The museum later expanded and was moved to its current location in 1966. The move to a larger location also included the addition of the Bishop Planetarium. “It was bigger than any planetarium you’d expect to see in a community of our size,” Jeff said. “And it was state-of-the-art when it was built. The community thinking was well ahead of its time.” After a fire in 2001, the planetarium was completely rebuilt and re-opened four years later. “Again, forward thinking,” Jeff noted. He explained that they again adopted state-of-the-art technology and become one of the first planetariums to use digital technology, which they continue to update as technology grows today. That includes a 3D digital map of the entire observable universe. 20180425115203-bishopstars-sk2zch1wzvekdvttz50bcis18q0ablzbh-rgb-l.jpeg Article-Subsection One of Jeff’s favorite planetarium presentations is a 19-minute show narrated by Tom Hanks called Passport to the Universe. The show takes you from Earth to the furthest edges of the known universe. “Invariably, people walk out with a different respect for their place in the universe,” Jeff said. “The word I hear most often is ‘insignificant’.” Attachment: 20180425115951-Img-0216.png A fan favorite section of the museum is undeniably the Parker Manatee Aquarium. In 1993, the museum became a founding member of the Manatee Rehabilitation Partnership and got their first rehab manatee in 1998. “We’ve cared for 36 manatees during our time in the partnership,” Jessica explained. “That’s really something we’re proud of – we really take in these manatees that were injured, or sick, or abandoned and then we care for them until they’re ready to be released back into the wild.” 20180425115951-img-0216.png Attachment: 20180425120441-Img-0247.png Often you’ll see visitors watching the manatees for long periods of time. “I think people like seeing their individual personalities,” Jessica said. “With the three we have right now, I’ve found that they’re curious about different things. It’s fun for visitors to see that they’re not just blobs in the water.” With all their knowledge and time spent in the museum, it's easy to forget that Jessica and Jeff are just regular Bradenton area locals. In their free time, Jessica enjoys the local craft breweries and Jeff spends his time in the many nature preserves. Both are foodies, and love how the local culinary scene is blossoming. 20180425120441-img-0247.png Article-Subsection Both Jessica and Jeff wants locals and visitors alike to understand that the South Florida Museum is constantly growing and evolving. “We’re not a dusty little hometown museum,” Jeff expressed. “There’s always something going on.” That includes their events, upcoming exhibits, and expansions, like their upcoming Mosiac Backyard Universe. “Stop by any day and I guarantee you’ll be surprised by something you encounter,” Jessica concluded. Article-Subsection The South Florida Museum is located at 201 10th Street West in Bradenton, Florida. They are open 10:00 AM - 5:00 PM Tuesday through Saturday, 12:00 PM - 5:00 PM Sunday, and are closed on Monday. Click here for their official website.

name: Adrenaline Row
searchable: Adrenaline Row Adrenaline Row Attachment Article-Subsection Celebrating Excitement Bradenton, Florida’s Adrenaline Row turns an anniversary into an adventure By Kelli Hann There’s nothing like moving to put a spotlight on how much stuff you have. Standing in the garage, staring at nearly a dozen boxes headed to charity, my husband, Rob, said, “We have to stop the madness.” From that moment on, all our gifts to each other have been “experience” gifts. Exotic restaurants, snorkeling, weekend getaways, beach days. Fun and adventure over things. So, when our wedding anniversary came up, we opted for an action-packed weekend of water sports. We wanted to pack in tons of activities without spending all weekend driving. With a quick web search, Rob discovered Adrenaline Row in Bradenton. Adrenaline Row is a mile-long strip of land that goes from Bradenton across Palma Sola Bay to Anna Maria Island. There’s a lot to do there: horseback riding (or surfing), the beach, jet skiing, kayaking, fishing, flyboarding…we had trouble choosing! Finally, after much discussion (and a snarky QuizUp battle to see who got to pick the hotel) I went online and reserved kayaks, jet skis, a horseback riding tour, and a flyboarding lesson. Our adrenaline-fueled anniversary in the Bradenton area was on! Do More Outdoors in Bradenton ➤ Share this Kayaking dream come true We arrived at our hotel Friday night, so we’d be ready to roll in the morning. After breakfast, we headed to The Surfer Bus. It’s an actual bus—vintage-beachy-surfer-cool, with SUPs strapped on top and paddles in blue, red and yellow leaning in a row against the wood-paneled side—we had just rolled into a 1960s surfer movie. The Surfer Bus is loaded with fun “C’mon Kelli, stop Instagramming and let’s go!” Rob insisted. Rob helped me launch my kayak into the calm water of the bay then eased in beside me. We chose the self-guided Robinson Preserve Tower Route. After crossing a short stretch of open water, we glided into a narrow passage with mangroves on either side that arched over us to form a tunnel. It was magical—all I could hear was the soft waves of the water against the mangrove roots and the occasional splash of Rob’s paddle. Light filtered through the canopy, making dots of sunlight dance like fairies. As soon as the path widened, I signaled Rob to go ahead of me so he could go through the next mangrove tunnel first. Make playful friends About halfway through the trip we were crossing a wide area together when suddenly Rob whispered, “Kelli, dolphins!” He was pointing just in front of us to the left. A few seconds later I heard a light huff then saw a fin rise out of the water, arching up then sliding back under without so much as a ripple. It was followed by another fin, another huff—two dolphins. I’d never seen dolphins in the wild and was shaking with excitement. Rob’s eyes were as big as plates and we were both grinning like fools. We got to see them surface six times before we turned back. Bucket list: kayak with dolphins. Check. Kayak with the dolphins in Bradenton ➤ Share this Two kinds of rides Wave from the waves Our next stop was across the street for jet skiing. We had no sooner hopped on when Rob shot off like a bullet. I punched it to keep up, leaning into the wind. Jet skiing always makes me giddy. It’s that same feeling you get when you run down a hill so fast your legs aren’t quite keeping up—that buzz you get when you’re part flying and part falling and completely free. “Watch this!” Rob called as he did a circle around me. Watch? Oh, no, not today. DO. The rest of the hour was spent trying to one-up each other, until Rob won the day with a daredevil move where he spun around to create waves, then revved the clutch to “hop” over them. I tried it, but only managed to drench myself. Even then, it was so much fun I didn’t want to head back in. But we had plans for dinner and a movie, so I hollered, “Last one back is the designated driver!” My cocktails were delicious. Water horse—not to be confused with a seahorse The next day we found ourselves back on Adrenaline Row, this time at BeachHorses™ to try HorseSurfing™. After getting to know our horses and trainers, our group of 12 rode in a jagged line along the beach. The day was hot, but the sun made both water and sand sparkle and I felt a wave of contentment. Soon we turned the horses and headed into the bay. As the cool water washed over my legs and up to my waist, I let it lift me slightly, gliding and floating at the same time, weightless. Once the horses were swimming (they swam surprisingly fast), the trainers showed us how to surf. It looked easy. When it was my turn to try, I got my legs under me in a frog crouch, planted my feet, slowly rose up, and SPLASH! After many tries, I finally got the rhythm of the horse’s swimming motion and managed to stay standing. “Take a picture, take a picture!” I yelled at Rob. Luckily, he was already on it—he’d been GoPro filming my wipeouts the whole time. When I was done, he handed me the camera and had his own clumsy go at it. That video is better than any anniversary present money could buy. Experience horse surfing in Bradenton ➤ Share this High intensity thrills Trade the high rise for a high ride! We closed out our trip with a flyboarding lesson at TOP GUN Flyboards. After a short how-to (and how not to) briefing, Rob rode out with our guide/guru, Jonathan. They got into position. There was a suspenseful moment of quiet then the jet ski that supplies the water propulsion to the flyboard rumbled to life. Slowly Rob rose out of the water. He got about a foot up before he fell backward, but he was soon up again. After about 15 minutes of short lifts and big falls, he seemed to get the hang of it and managed a few wobbly spins. Watching Rob have all that fun had me psyched to try it. As soon as the jet ski revved up and I started to lift out of the water, I knew I was hard-core hooked. There was nothing holding me down or back. No resistance of equipment or gravity. I was floating, flying—I was a superhero. Rising out of the water, hovering in the air with my arms hanging loose by my sides. Fly like a superhero in Bradenton ➤ Share this Adrenaline Row junkies “How soon can we come back?” I asked as we headed home. “Well, my birthday is coming up.” “The clerk at the hotel lobby told me the Palma Sola Causeway Park right there on Adrenaline Row rented pavilions with grills and tables. We could invite Jenna and Chris, have easy access to all the Adrenaline Row stuff, and then have a cookout.” “Sounds perfect. Let’s do it.” Looks like Adrenaline Row is a gift that’s going to keep on giving. Discover more exciting things to do outdoors in Bradenton, Florida. Related Stories

meta_title: 5 Things You (Probably) Didn't Know About the Bradenton Area
meta_description: You’ve seen our amazing beaches, delicious dining, and funky downtown core. But in the Bradenton Area, there’s more to our destination than meets the eye. Here are five things that you (probably) didn't know about Bradenton, Anna Maria Island, and Longboat Key.

But in the Bradenton Area, there’s more to our destination than meets the eye. Here are five things that you (probably) didn't know about Bradenton, Anna Maria Island, and Longboat Key.Attachment: 20180705120810-O-Briens-Field-And-Barn-Sm6Okw00-1Pd9Pob3R1Cu3T18Q0Ablzbh-Rgb-L.jpeg 20180705120810-o-briens-field-and-barn-sm6okw00-1pd9pob3r1cu3t18q0ablzbh-rgb-l.jpeg Deck You’ve seen our amazing beaches, delicious dining, and funky downtown core. But in the Bradenton Area, there’s more to our destination than meets the eye. Here are five things that you (probably) didn't know about Bradenton, Anna Maria Island, and Longboat Key. Html Container Article-Subsection 1. The Air Smells Like Oranges Imagine taking a stroll down the Riverwalk, or cruising through Village of the Arts when all of a sudden you get a delightful citrusy whiff. Thanks to the nearby Tropicana plant, that’s exactly the case when you’re in the Bradenton Area! Whenever the OJ King burns the orange peels they use to make their iconic juice the area around the plant smells heavenly, and exactly like Florida should smell. Attachment: 20180627155929-Frame-Template-Polaroids.png 2. We Take Sustainability Seriously You may have strolled the charming shops of Pine Avenue on Anna Maria Island, but did you know that it’s considered the “Greenest Little Main Street in America”? The candy colored buildings lining this road may make it look like a regular beach town, but they are actually all platinum LEED-certified and solar powered! Along with the native Florida plants, community gardens, and crushed shell sidewalks, Pine Avenue is a true modern marvel when it comes to sustainability. Some other eco-friendly places to visit when you’re in the Bradenton Area are Bunker Hill Winery, which uses only recycled wine bottles and real cork along with a solar powered irrigation system, and the U-Pick area at O’Brien Family Farms that boasts dozens of types of hydroponically grown fresh fruits and veggies. 20180627155929-frame-template-polaroids.png Attachment: 20180627160838-Frame-Template-M-Shell.png 3. Our Sand Has Health Benefits From building sand castles to beachfront dining there’s plenty of ways to enjoy the powder-soft sand found on the beaches of the Bradenton Area. But even better the sand can be used as a natural exfoliant! The soft quartz sand of Anna Maria Island and Longboat Key has fantastic benefits when used for exfoliating and once it’s washed off it will leave your skin smooth and healthy for the rest of your vacation. 20180627160838-frame-template-m-shell.png Attachment: 20180627161525-Frame-Template-Sunglasses.png 4. We Create Athletes The Bradenton Area is home to IMG Academy, a sport training facility and boarding school that has produced hundreds of world-class athletes. It was founded in 1978 by Nick Bollettieri as a Tennis Academy and now trains children and adults in eight different sports. If you’re vacationing in the Bradenton Area and itching to practice your swing, IMG offers a variety of camps for different sports and even has its own elegant hotel right on campus! 20180627161525-frame-template-sunglasses.png Article-Subsection 5. We’re Committed to Local Flavor In the Bradenton Area you don’t have look hard to find locally sourced meals. The area has the great fortune of being one of the few Florida destinations that feature fabulous beaches on the coast and local farms on the mainland. Many of the restaurants you’ll find out on the island source their food directly from nearby farms, and even purchase their seafood from the still-thriving commercial fishing village of Cortez. So when you bite into that grouper sandwich or a fresh veggie salad, you’ll feel good knowing exactly where your food came from.

name: So You're From New York...
meta_description: Need a break from The Big Apple? You’re in luck! In the Bradenton Area you can enjoy spectacular beaches, a laid back atmosphere, and gourmet dining all in the same destination.
searchable: So You're From New York... So You're From New York... Need a break from The Big Apple? You’re in luck! In the Bradenton Area you can enjoy spectacular beaches, a laid back atmosphere, and gourmet dining all in the same destination.Attachment: 20180803121758-Beach-Smr-Nen5Cutof9Jfqadhbdr18Q0Ablzbh-Rgb-L.jpeg 20180803121758-beach-smr-nen5cutof9jfqadhbdr18q0ablzbh-rgb-l.jpeg Deck Need a break from The Big Apple? You’re in luck! In the Bradenton Area you can enjoy spectacular beaches, a laid back atmosphere, and gourmet dining all in the same destination. Html Container Article-Subsection First, hop on a plane and enjoy a brief, non-stop flight into Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport. Coming from Queens? Delta has daily flights right out of LaGuardia. Living the Brooklyn life? Jet Blue has you covered at JFK. Maybe you’re on the West Side? No worries – there’s daily flights out of Newark on United, too! No matter which airport you choose to use, you’ll still find yourself on the sugar-white sands of Anna Maria Island in a matter of just a few hours. Attachment: 20180803153020-Frame-Template-Sunglasses.png Yes, that’s correct – just a few hours! We know you have a pick of nearby different beach options living in NYC, but the Jersey Shore beaches aren’t exactly vacation friendly in the winter (plus, it’s, you know, in Jersey). And no beach destination can beat the Bradenton Area’s pristine white beaches and peaceful relaxation away from the crowds and high rises. We know you live a hectic life in the big city, so while you’re here make sure you switch your internal clock’s settings to island time. Yes, life in the Bradenton Area is slow and calm – exactly what you need to get away from the busy streets of Manhattan. Here you can exchange honking for sea gull caws and heavy traffic for free trolleys. 20180803153020-frame-template-sunglasses.png Attachment: 20180803154155-Dddd.png There’s never a bad time to visit the Bradenton Area, but for you we think you’d especially enjoy our winters. Our sand may be pure white, but there’s no snow here – just comfortable temperatures and sea breezes. We know things can get pretty frigid up there so what better a way to spend your December or January than in tropical paradise? Afraid you’ll find yourself missing home? Fuhgeddaboudit! Gio Fabulous Pizza & Martini Bar in Bradenton has authentic New York-style pizza that will make you feel right at home. Their pizza slices are just the right size to be folded (the proper way to eat pizza, of course). Don’t miss out on their stylish martini bar while you’re there! 20180803154155-dddd.png Attachment: 20180803161229-Frame-Template-Polaroids.png Another highlight you might enjoy? Shopping. Yes, we know you could buy anything your heart desires in NYC when it comes to traditional shopping, but we think you’d enjoy something a little different while you’re vacationing. The shops of Pine Avenue on Anna Maria Island are charming and unique. Here you can slowly stroll the Key West style buildings and pick up everything from adorable souvenirs (think – a hand painted sand dollar) to trendy boutique finds that you’ll be dying to wear when summer returns. And while your vacation can’t last forever, we hope that spending some time under the Florida sun will help returning to your hectic life just a little bit easier. And don’t worry – with everything the Bradenton Area has to offer New Yorkers like you, we’re sure you’ll find yourself making plans to return soon. 20180803161229-frame-template-polaroids.png

In the Bradenton Area, you can enjoy amazing beaches, gourmet dining, exciting activities, and enthusing sports all without having to take off that Pirates ball cap. Html Container Article-Subsection First, arrive the easy way by taking a non-stop flight on Allegiant to Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport. Once your wheels are off the ground at PIT it’ll just be 3 short hours before your toes are in the sugar-soft sands of Anna Maria Island. Attachment: 20180806095422-S.png There’s never a bad time to visit the Bradenton Area, but for you, there’s one time to visit that you won’t want to miss: Spring Training. Your Pittsburgh Pirates made Bradenton their southern home since 1969 and are a huge part of the Bradenton Area’s community. The best part? You’ll get to experience some history of America’s pastime because LECOM Park (formerly McKechnie Field) is the old operating Spring Training facility in professional baseball, and the third oldest ballpark used in major league baseball (behind just Fenway and Wrigley)! Even if you’ve been to the Bradenton Area before, there are probably some things that you didn’t know that will make you love your vacation spot even more. For instance – did you know that Bradenton is the official sister city of Pittsburgh? Yes, in 2011 the two cities formed a two city alliance in an effort to show their loyalty to one another. How did they do that? Over a game of baseball, naturally. 20180806095422-s.png Attachment: 20180806093410-Frame-Template-Orange.png Feeling homesick? No worries, Fanatics Sports Bar & Grill in Bradenton has you covered. Here you’ll find like-minded individuals who just want to sit down with a Yuengling and a burger and catch the Steelers game. Just be sure to arrive early – this place fills up with gold and black jerseys fast! And while you won’t want to miss a single rousing ball game, you might want to add some extra time to your trip to the Bradenton Area. No trip is complete without spending hours on our pristine beaches, but there’s more that we think you might like. For instance – try meeting the rehab manatees at the South Florida Museum’s Manatee Aquarium. Or grab a cocktail while listening to live music on historic Bridge Street on Anna Maria Island. Even better, tour an authentic Florida orange grove at Mixon Fruit Farms, and send your family back a beautiful basket of gift fruit. 20180806093410-frame-template-orange.png Attachment: 20180806094338-Frame-Ss.png Yes, dear Yinzer, you’ve come to the right place to start planning your Bradenton Area vacation. We think you’ll love the variety of accommodations options – from historic hotels near the ballpark to luxurious private homes on the island, you’ll surely find the perfect place to stay. Be sure to check out everything the destination has to offer and of course, go Bucs! 20180806094338-frame-ss.png

name: The Top 10 Things to See and Do in Bradenton
meta_description: The city of Bradenton is full of rich culture and natural beauty. While it would be nearly impossible to list all of the exciting things the city has to offer, this list is a good place to start. Here are some of the top 10 things to see and do in Bradenton.
searchable: The Top 10 Things to See and Do in Bradenton The-Top-10-Things-to-See-and-Do-in-Bradenton The city of Bradenton is full of rich culture and natural beauty. While it would be nearly impossible to list all of the exciting things the city has to offer, this list is a good place to start. Here are some of the top 10 things to see and do in Bradenton.Attachment: 20171228191800-Palms-Downtown-Bradenton-Sbbdooqo5Zbd9Mq9Yhaxyfo-Rgb-S.jpeg 20171228191800-palms-downtown-bradenton-sbbdooqo5zbd9mq9yhaxyfo-rgb-s.jpeg Deck The city of Bradenton is full of rich culture and natural beauty. While it would be nearly impossible to list all of the exciting things the city has to offer, this list is a good place to start. Here are some of the top 10 things to see and do in Bradenton. Html Container Article-Subsection 1. The Bradenton Riverwalk Spanning 1.5 miles along the sparkling Manatee River, the Bradenton Riverwalk is a great way to spend your sunny Florida afternoon. Grab a sweet treat at Corwin’s Ice Cream and Smoothies and hang out on one of the outdoor livings rooms, or bring the family and enjoy the splashpad and playground. There is truly something for everyone! Attachment: 20171228192317-South-Florida-Museum-Spi0Enb4Qiuejvhfw6-Eyzn-Rgb-L.jpeg 2. The South Florida Museum Boasting a natural history museum, a state-of-the-art planetarium, and a second stage rehabilitation aquarium for injured manatees, the South Florida Museum is a gem not to be missed. With all it has to offer – from learning about some of the oldest history known about Florida to watching the gentle giants of the sea do barrel rolls in their temporary home – it’s easy to spend hours in this small but mighty museum. 20171228192317-south-florida-museum-spi0enb4qiuejvhfw6-eyzn-rgb-l.jpeg Article-Subsection 3. Village of the Arts This collection of brightly painted old Florida bungalows is home to one of the largest live-work artist communities in the country. The funky neighborhood includes unique galleries, mouth-watering restaurants, and even yoga studios and mystics! It’s without a doubt the perfect place to get a special souvenir. Attachment: 20171228192632-Mckechnie-Field-At-Night-Sjd1Nzmtgp531Vxkjinh2Ot18Q0Ablzbh-Rgb-S.jpeg 4. LECOM Park One of the oldest operating ballparks in the world, LECOM Park has plenty of fun to offer, from local craft brews on tap to its 360 degree views of the field. And with it being the home of the Pittsburgh Pirates during the spring and full time home of the Bradenton Marauders, it’s easy to catch a game almost any time! 20171228192632-mckechnie-field-at-night-sjd1nzmtgp531vxkjinh2ot18q0ablzbh-rgb-s.jpeg Attachment: 20171228192857-Manatee-Historic-Village-Park-Church-Svirofz5Oytd4S5Gknnufor18Q0Ablzbh-Rgb-S.jpeg 5. Manatee Village Historical Park Even paradise has a history, especially a city as old as Bradenton (established in 1842), and Manatee Village Historical Park is a great way to explore that history! The park is home to a collection of some of the oldest Bradenton has to offer, including the town’s original community church, the 1903 Wiggins General Store, a 1912 Florida pioneer farmhouse and an 1800’s original settler graveyard. 20171228192857-manatee-historic-village-park-church-svirofz5oytd4s5gknnufor18q0ablzbh-rgb-s.jpeg Article-Subsection 6. Old Manatee Nearby the historic Village is the area of Old Manatee. While it’s one of the oldest parts of Bradenton, this area boasts fresh restaurants like Central Café and Drago’s, and fun shopping for vintage items at Retro Rosie’s and shabby chic home décor at The Farmhouse. An added bonus: The Farmhouse makes delicious custom made-to-order mini donuts that are the perfect way to treat yourself. Attachment: 20171228193230-Motorworks-Brewing-Saq1Fudx4As3Wm-Iem9Mwkp-Cmyk-S.jpeg 7. Breweries Bradenton is a city dedicated to living local, and that extends to its beer. Craft breweries like Darwin Brewing Company, Motorworks Brewing and 3 Keys Brewing and Eatery use local flavors to make some tasty brews that are best enjoyed while relaxing under the warm Florida sun. 20171228193230-motorworks-brewing-saq1fudx4as3wm-iem9mwkp-cmyk-s.jpeg Article-Subsection 8. The Manatee Performing Arts Center You don’t have to hit Broadway to catch an outstanding show. At Manatee Performing Arts Center you can see a professional-grade play sure to make your emotions soar. The theater puts on shows ranging from family-friendly musicals to thought-provoking dramas so you’re sure to find something everyone will want to watch. Article-Subsection 9. Farm Tours Head east of downtown and you’ll see that the rich Florida farm culture is alive and well in Bradenton. The area has everything from authentic Florida orange farms to large dairy farms where you can feed a baby calf! For the freshest of fresh fruit, head to O’Brien Family Farms for a U-Pick extravaganza. And if you really want something different, try doing some yoga with goats at Geraldson Community Farm! Attachment: 20171228193635-Art-Gallery-Study-Sxnbbcy4Mdnrr-Gfyudrwao-Cmyk-S.jpeg 10. ArtCenter Manatee The cultural hub of Bradenton, ArtCenter Manatee is the premier place to get your art on. The center features three galleries with breathtaking monthly exhibits, five classrooms for their fun and unique classes, and an artists’ market gift shop that’s the perfect place to find a special gift or souvenir made by a local artist. ArtCenter Manatee is one of the best ways to enjoy the rich artistic culture that makes Bradenton special. 20171228193635-art-gallery-study-sxnbbcy4mdnrr-gfyudrwao-cmyk-s.jpeg Article-Subsection Pro Tip: Walk Bradenton Looking for something specific? Fortunately there is a handy website called Walk Bradenton. Let this tool be your tour guide in the palm of your hand. Just pull it up on your phone or mobile device and you’ll see everything around you that Bradenton has to offer! And with ten different categories to choose from, such as history, dining, shopping and more, you’re sure to find something nearby that piques your interest.

Fortunately for you – and your significant other – Anna Maria Island is a peaceful hidden gem that is sure to make your romantic long weekend an unforgettable one. Html Container Attachment: 20180820104910-Frame-Template-Shell.png It all starts with the perfect accommodation. The enchanting Bungalow Beach Resort is the top place to relax and reconnect with your loved one. Their 1930’s cedar clapboard bungalows have been preserved to maintain their old Florida charm, and are so cozy that you might find yourself struggling not to stay inside all weekend. Fortunately, Bungalow Beach Resort is situated on the alluring soft white sand of Anna Maria Island, so you won’t be able to resist the need to stroll their private beach hand-in-hand while enjoying a one-of-a-kind sunset. 20180820104910-frame-template-shell.png Attachment: 20180820105328-Frame-Template-Sunglasses.png The next morning you’ll want to hit the shops of nearby Bridge Street. This historic area has restaurants, shops and entertainment that will have something for both of you to enjoy. Start with a meal with a view – Anna Maria Oyster Bar, located on the Bridge Street Pier, serves a hearty brunch, including mimosas and bloody marys, and will leave you stuffed and ready to continue your leisurely day. Stroll down to Sea-renity Beach Spa & Eco Boutique for a couples massage. Be sure to ask them about their beach massage option for maximum relaxation. After your muscles are loose, meander down to Back Alley Treasures. Try one of their local craft beers, an espresso (biscotti included), or share a flight of tasty wines. Then head over to the Fish Hole for some mini-golf, because a little friendly competition never hurt anyone! 20180820105328-frame-template-sunglasses.png Attachment: 20180820105907-Frame-Template-Shell.png After taking a tranquil rest back at your bungalow, head to Beach Bistro for one of the most romantic settings Anna Maria Island has to offer. This award-winning Zagat-rated restaurant has been named one of the most romantic restaurants in America – and for good reason. Here, you’ll enjoy a gourmet meal while watching the sunset from a private beach – and be sure to end your evening with one of their decadent desserts. 20180820105907-frame-template-shell.png Attachment: 20180820110301-Frame-Template-Polaroids.png On your final morning, pick up a tandem bike from Beach Bums and explore more of what the island has to offer. Check out the quaint shops of Pine Avenue – perhaps you’ll find a piece of unique jewelry at Island Cabana, or enjoy some olive oil tastings at Olive Oil Outpost. After saying goodbye to your lovely home-away-from-home, spend one last moment cozying up on the serene Bean Point beach. Enjoy the incredible views of the iconic Sunshine Skyway Bridge and the glimmering waters of Tampa Bay. 20180820110301-frame-template-polaroids.png Article-Subsection
